dependencies.name: dart:core
dependencies.comment:
Built-in types, collections,
and other core functionality for every Dart program.

This library is automatically imported.

Some classes in this library,
such as [String] and [num],
support Dart's built-in data types.
Other classes, such as [List] and [Map], provide data structures
for managing collections of objects.
And still other classes represent commonly used types of data
such as URIs, dates and times, and errors.

## Numbers and booleans

[int] and [double] provide support for Dart's built-in numerical data types:
integers and double-precision floating point numbers, respectively.
An object of type [bool] is either true or false.
Variables of these types can be constructed from literals:

    int meaningOfLife = 42;
    double valueOfPi  = 3.141592;
    bool visible      = true;

## Strings and regular expressions

A [String] is immutable and represents a sequence of characters.

    String shakespeareQuote = "All the world's a stage, ...";

[StringBuffer] provides a way to construct strings efficiently.

    StringBuffer moreShakespeare = new StringBuffer();
    moreShakespeare.write('And all the men and women ');
    moreShakespeare.write('merely players; ...');

The String and StringBuffer classes implement string concatenation,
interpolation, and other string manipulation features.

    String philosophy = 'Live on ';
    String get palindrome => philosophy + philosophy.split('').reversed.join();

[RegExp] implements Dart regular expressions,
which provide a grammar for matching patterns within text.
For example, here's a regular expression that matches
a string of one or more digits:

    var numbers = new RegExp(r'\d+');

Dart regular expressions have the same syntax and semantics as
JavaScript regular expressions. See
<http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-15.10>
for the specification of JavaScript regular expressions.

## Collections

The dart:core library provides basic collections,
such as [List], [Map], and [Set].

A List is an ordered collection of objects, with a length.
Lists are sometimes called arrays.
Use a List when you need to access objects by index.

    List superheroes = [ 'Batman', 'Superman', 'Harry Potter' ];

A Set is an unordered collection of unique objects.
You cannot get an item by index (position).
Adding a duplicate item has no effect.

    Set villians = new Set();
    villians.add('Joker');
    villians.addAll( ['Lex Luther', 'Voldemort'] );

A Map is an unordered collection of key-value pairs.
Maps are sometimes called associative arrays because
maps associate a key to some value for easy retrieval.
Keys are unique.
Use a Map when you need to access objects
by a unique identifier.

    Map sidekicks = { 'Batman': 'Robin',
                      'Superman': 'Lois Lane',
                      'Harry Potter': 'Ron and Hermione' };

In addition to these classes,
dart:core contains [Iterable],
an interface that defines functionality
common in collections of objects.
Examples include the ability
to run a function on each element in the collection,
to apply a test to each element,
to retrieve an object, and to determine length.

Iterable is implemented by List and Set,
and used by Map for its keys and values.

For other kinds of collections, check out the
[dart:collection](#dart-collection) library.

## Date and time

Use [DateTime] to represent a point in time
and [Duration] to represent a span of time.

You can create DateTime objects with constructors
or by parsing a correctly formatted string.

    DateTime now = new DateTime.now();
    DateTime berlinWallFell = new DateTime(1989, 11, 9);
    DateTime moonLanding = DateTime.parse("1969-07-20");

Create a Duration object specifying the individual time units.

    Duration timeRemaining = new Duration(hours:56, minutes:14);

In addition to DateTime and Duration,
dart:core contains the [Stopwatch] class for measuring elapsed time.

## Uri

A [Uri] object represents a uniform resource identifier,
which identifies a resource on the web.

    Uri dartlang = Uri.parse('http://dartlang.org/');

## Errors

The [Error] class represents the occurrence of an error
during runtime.
Subclasses of this class represent specific kinds of errors.

## Other documentation

For more information about how to use the built-in types, refer to
[Built-in Types](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch02.html#built-in-types)
in Chapter 2 of
[Dart: Up and Running](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/).

Also, see
[dart:core - Numbers, Collections, Strings, and More](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html#ch03-dartcore---strings-collections-and-more)
for more coverage of classes in this package.

The
[Dart Language Specification](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/spec/)
provides technical details.

children.name: Object
children.comment:
The base class for all Dart objects.

Because Object is the root of the Dart class hierarchy,
every other Dart class is a subclass of Object.

When you define a class, you should override [toString]
to return a string describing an instance of that class.
You might also need to define [hashCode] and [==], as described in the
[Implementing map keys]
(http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html#ch03-implementing-map-keys)
section of the [library tour]
(http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html).

The equality operator.

The default behavior for all [Object]s is to return true if and
only if [:this:] and [other] are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on
a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation.
That is, it must be:

 * Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw
   or return `null`.

 * Reflexive: For all objects `o`, `o == o` must be true.

 * Symmetric: For all objects `o1` and `o2`, `o1 == o2` and `o2 == o1` must
   either both be true, or both be false.

 * Transitive: For all objects `o1`, `o2`, and `o3`, if `o1 == o2` and
   `o2 == o3` are true, then `o1 == o3` must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects
should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects
was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override
the [hashCode] method as well to maintain consistency.

children.name: toString
children.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

children.name: noSuchMethod
children.comment:
[noSuchMethod] is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method
on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the
invocation are passed to [noSuchMethod] in an [Invocation].
If [noSuchMethod] returns a value, that value becomes the result of
the original invocation.

The default behavior of [noSuchMethod] is to throw a
[NoSuchMethodError].

children.name: hashCode
children.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the
same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality
operator [:==:]. Other than that there are no guarantees about
the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and
there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides [hashCode] it should override the
equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

children.name: runtimeType
children.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

Creates a new [Object] instance.

[Object] instances have no meaningful state, and are only useful
through their identity. An [Object] instance is equal to itself
only.

children.name: Comparable
children.comment: Interface used by types that have an intrinsic ordering.

children.name: compareTo
children.comment:
Compares this object to another [Comparable]

Returns a value like a [Comparator] when comparing [:this:] to [other].

May throw an [ArgumentError] if [other] is of a type that
is not comparable to [:this:].

children.name: compare
children.comment:
Compare one comparable to another.

This utility function is used as the default comparator
for the [List] sort function.

comment:
A math library for parsing and evaluating expressions in real, interval and
vector contexts. It also supports simplification and differentiation of
expressions.

The libary supports the three basic data types [Number], [Interval]s and
[Vector]. It includes a [Parser] to create [Expression]s from Strings.

children.name: ContextModel
children.comment: The context model keeps track of all known variables and functions.

children.name: getExpression
children.comment:
Returns the bound expression for the given variable.

Throws a StateError, if variable is not bound.

children.name: getFunction
children.comment:
Returns the function for the given function name.

Throws a StateError, if function is not bound.

children.name: bindGlobalVariable
children.comment: Binds a variable to an expression in this context.

children.name: bindGlobalVariableName
children.comment: Binds a variable name to an expression in this context.

children.name: bindGlobalFunction
children.comment: Binds a function to this context.

children.name: variables
children.comment: Variable map (name -> bound expression).
Creates a new, empty context model.

children.name: EvaluationType
children.comment:
Mathematical expressions must be evaluated under a certain [EvaluationType].

Currently there are three types, but not all expressions support each type.
If you try to evaluate an expression with an unsupported type, it will raise an
[UnimplementedError] or [UnsupportedError].

- REAL
- VECTOR
- INTERVAL

__Note__: This class emulates an enumeration, since they are not supported
by Dart yet.
Two types are equal, if their internal int matches.

children.name: REAL
children.comment: Public constructor for REAL types. Always returns the same instance of a REAL type.

children.name: VECTOR
children.comment: Public constructor for VECTOR types. Always returns the same instance of a VECTOR type.

children.name: INTERVAL
children.comment: Public constructor for INTERVAL types. Always returns the same instance of a INTERVAL type.

children.name: _cache
children.comment: Our type map.

children.name: REAL_INT
children.comment: Internal integer value for REAL type.

children.name: VECTOR_INT
children.comment: Internal integer value for VECTOR type.

children.name: INTERVAL_INT
children.comment: Internal integer value for INTERVAL type.

children.name: _private
children.comment:
Private singleton constructor, no need to instantiate new objects
all the time.

children.name: _internal
children.comment: Internal constructor for EvaluationTypes.

children.name: TokenType
children.comment:
A token type. Access token types via the static final fields.

For example, to access the token type PLUS:
    plusType = TokenType.PLUS;

The type defines the [priority] (precedence) of the token.
    (+,-) < (*,/) < (^) < (-u) < functions
    
It also defines the [associativity] of the token. True stands for
left-associative, false for right-associative.

children.name: value
children.comment: The string value of this token type.

children.name: priority
children.comment: The priority of this token type.

children.name: leftAssociative
children.comment: Associativity of this token type. true = left.

children.name: operator
children.comment: True, if this token is an operator.

children.name: function
children.comment: True, if this token is a function.

children.name: _internal
children.comment:
Internal constructor for a [TokenType].
To retrieve a token type, directly access the static final fields
provided by this class.

children.name: Token
children.comment: A Token consists of text and has a [TokenType].
Tokens equal, if they have equal text and types.

children.name: text
children.comment: The text of this token.

children.name: type
children.comment: The type of this token.
Creates a new Token with the given text and type.

children.name: Lexer
children.comment:
The lexer creates tokens (see [TokenType] and [Token]) from an input string.
The input string is expected to be in
[infix notation form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infix_notation).
The lexer can convert an infix stream into a
[postfix stream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_Polish_notation)
(Reverse Polish Notation) for further processing by a [Parser].

children.name: tokenize
children.comment:
Tokenizes a given input string.
Returns a list of [Token] in infix notation.

children.name: _doIntBuffer
children.comment:
Checks if the intBuffer contains a number and adds it to the tokenStream.
Then clears the intBuffer.

children.name: _doVarBuffer
children.comment:
Checks if the varBuffer contains a keyword or a variable and adds them to the tokenStream.
Then clears the varBuffer.

children.name: shuntingYard
children.comment:
Transforms the lexer's token stream into RPN using the Shunting-yard
algorithm. Returns a list of [Token] in RPN form. Throws an
[ArgumentError] if the list is empty.

children.name: tokenizeToRPN
children.comment:
This method invokes the createTokenStream methode to create an infix token
stream and then invokes the shunting yard method to transform this stream
into a RPN (reverse polish notation) token stream.

children.name: intBuffer
children.comment: Buffer for numbers

children.name: varBuffer
children.comment: Buffer for variable and function names
Creates a new lexer.

children.name: Parser
parse
children.comment:
Parses the given input string into an [Expression]. Throws a
[ArgumentError] if the given [inputString] is empty. Throws a
[StateError] if the token stream is invalid. Returns a valid
[Expression].
Creates a new parser.

children.name: Tan
children.comment: The tangens function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. tan(0) = 0

children.name: asSinCos
children.comment:
Returns this tangens as sine and cosine representation.

`tan(x) = sin(x) / cos(x)`

children.name: arg
children.comment: The argument of this tangens function.
Creates a new tangens function with given argument expression.

children.name: Cos
children.comment: The cosine function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. cos(0) = 1

children.name: arg
children.comment: The argument of this cosine function.
Creates a new cosine function with given argument expression.

children.name: Sin
children.comment: The sine function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. sin(0) = 0

children.name: arg
children.comment: The argument of this sine function.
Creates a new sine function with given argument expression.

children.name: Sqrt
children.comment: The square root function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. sqrt(x^2) = x
2. sqrt(0) = 0
3. sqrt(1) = 1

Note: This simplification works _only_ for real numbers and
_not_ for complex numbers.

children.name: Root
children.comment: The n-th root function. n needs to be a natural number.

children.name: simplify
children.comment: Simplify argument.

children.name: asPower
children.comment:
Returns the power form of this root.
E.g. root_5(x) = x^(1/5)

This method is used to determine the derivation of a root
expression.

children.name: n
children.comment: N-th root.

children.name: fromExpr
children.comment: Creates the n-th root of arg where n is a [Number] literal.

children.name: sqrt
children.comment:
Creates the square root of arg.

For example, to create the square root of x:
    sqrt = new Root.sqrt(new Variable('x'));

Note: For better simplification and display, use the [Sqrt] class.

children.name: Ln
children.comment: The natural logarithm (log based e).

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. ln(1) = 0

children.name: Log
children.comment: The logarithm function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment: Simplifies base and argument.

children.name: asNaturalLogarithm
children.comment:
Returns the natural from of this logarithm.
E.g. log_10(2) = ln(2) / ln(10)

This method is used to determine the derivation of a logarithmic
expression.

children.name: base
children.comment: The base of this logarithm.

children.name: arg
children.comment: The argument of this logarithm.

children.name: _ln
children.comment:
Creates a natural logarithm.
Must only be used internally by the Ln class.

children.name: Exponential
children.comment: The exponential function.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. e^0 = 1
2. e^1 = e
3. e^(x*ln(y)) = y^x (usually easier to read for humans)

children.name: exp
children.comment: The exponent of this exponential function.

children.name: DefaultFunction
children.comment:
A default function is predefined in this library.
It contains no expression, because the appropriate [Evaluator] knows
how to handle them.

__Note__:
User-defined custom functions should derive from [CustomFunction], which
supports arbitrary expressions.

children.name: _wrapIntoVariable
children.comment:
Returns a variable, bound to the given [Expression].
Returns the parameter itself, if it is already a variable.

children.name: _unary
children.comment:
Creates a new unary function with given name and argument.
If the argument is not a variable, it will be wrapped into an anonymous
variable, which binds the given expression.

__Note__:
Must only be used internally for pre-defined functions, as it does not
contain any expression. The Evaluator needs to know how to handle this.

children.name: _binary
children.comment:
Creates a new binary function with given name and two arguments.
If the arguments are not variables, they will be wrapped into anonymous
variables, which bind the given expressions.

__Note__:
Must only be used internally for pre-defined functions, as it does not
contain any expression. The Evaluator needs to know how to handle this.

children.name: CustomFunction
children.comment: Any user-created function is a CustomFunction.

children.name: expression
children.comment:
Function expression of this function.
Used for non-default or user-defined functions.

Create a custom function with the given name, argument variables,
and expression.

children.name: CompositeFunction
children.comment: A composition of two given [MathFunction]s.

children.name: simplify
children.comment: Simplifies both component functions.

children.name: gDomainDimension
children.comment:
The domain of the 'second' function, which should match the range
of the 'first function.

children.name: domainDimension
children.comment: The domain of the 'first' function.

children.name: f
children.comment: Members `f` and `g` of the composite function.

children.name: g
children.comment: Members `f` and `g` of the composite function.

Creates a function composition.

For example, given `f(x): R -> R^3` and `g(x,y,z): R^3 -> R`
the composition yields `(g Â° f)(x): R -> R^3 -> R`. First
`f` is applied, then `g` is applied.

Given some requirements
    x = new Variable('x');
    xPlus = new Plus(x, 1);
    xMinus = new Minus(x, 1);

    fExpr = new Vector([x, xPlus, xMinus]);        // Transforms x to 3-dimensional vector
    f = new CustomFunction('f', [x], fExpr);       // Creates a function R -> R^3 from fExpr

    y = new Variable('z');
    z = new Variable('y');

    gExpr = x + y + z;                             // Transforms 3-dimensional input to real value
    g = new CustomFunction('g', [x, y, z], gExpr)  // Creates a function R^3 -> R from gExpr

a composition can be created as follows:
    composite = new CompositeFunction(f, g); // R -> R
                                             // composite(2) = 6

children.name: MathFunction
children.comment:
A function with an arbitrary number of arguments.

__Note:__ Functions do not offer auto-wrapping of arguments into [Literal]s.
Compose operator. Creates a [CompositeFunction].

children.name: getParam
children.comment: Returns the i-th parameter of this function.

children.name: toFullString
children.comment:
Returns the full string representation of this function.
This could include the name, variables and expression.

Any subclass should decide whether to override this method.

children.name: domainDimension
children.comment: The dimension of the domain of definition of this function.

children.name: name
children.comment: Name of this function.

children.name: args
children.comment:
List of arguments of this function.
Must be a variable.
Creates a new function with the given name and arguments.

children.name: _empty
children.comment:
Creates a new function with the given name.

__Note__:
Must only be used internally by subclasses, as it does not define any
arguments.

children.name: IntervalLiteral
children.comment: An interval literal.
Creates a new interval with given borders.

children.name: fromSingle
children.comment: Creates a new interval with identical borders.

children.name: BoundVariable
children.comment:
A bound variable is an anonymous variable, e.g. a variable without name,
which is bound to an expression.
Creates an anonymous variable which is bound to the given expression.

children.name: Variable
children.comment: A variable is a named literal.
Creates a variable literal with given name.

children.name: Vector
children.comment: A vector of arbitrary size.

children.name: simplify
children.comment: Simplifies all elements of this vector.

children.name: elements
children.comment: The elements of this vector.

children.name: length
children.comment: The length of this vector.

children.name: Number
children.comment: A number is a constant number literal.

Creates a number literal with given value.
Always holds a double internally.

children.name: Literal
children.comment: A literal can be a number, a constant or a variable.

children.name: isConstant
children.comment: Returns true, if this literal is a constant.

children.name: getConstantValue
children.comment:
Returns the constant value of this literal.
Throws StateError if literal is not constant, check before usage with
`isConstant()`.

Creates a literal. The optional paramter `value` can be used to specify
its value.

children.name: Power
children.comment: The power operator.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. 0^x = 0
2. 1^x = 1
3. x^0 = 1
4. x^1 = x

children.name: asE
children.comment:
Returns the exponential form of this operation.
E.g. x^4 = e^(4*ln(x))

This method is used to determine the derivation of a power expression.

children.name: Divide
children.comment: The divide operator performs a division.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. -a / b = - (a / b)
2. a * -b = - (a / b)
3. -a / -b = a / b
5. 0 / a = 0
6. a / 1 = a

children.name: evaluate
children.comment:
This method throws an [IntegerDivisionByZeroException],
if a divide by zero is encountered.

children.name: Times
children.comment: The times operator performs a multiplication.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. -a * b = - (a * b)
2. a * -b = - (a * b)
3. -a * -b = a * b
4. a * 0 = 0
5. 0 * a = 0
6. a * 1 = a
7. 1 * a = a

children.name: Minus
children.comment: The minus operator performs a subtraction.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. a - 0 = a
2. 0 - a = - a
3. a - -(b) = a + b

children.name: Plus
children.comment: The plus operator performs an addition.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. a + 0 = a
2. 0 + a = a
3. a + -(b) = a - b

children.name: UnaryMinus
children.comment: The unary minus negates its argument.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Possible simplifications:

1. -(-a) = a
2. -0 = 0

children.name: UnaryOperator
children.comment: A unary operator takes one argument and performs an operation on it.

Creates a [UnaryOperation] from the given argument.

If the argument is not an expression, it will be wrapped in an appropriate
literal.

* A (positive) number will be encapsulated in a [Number] Literal,
* A string will be encapsulated in a [Variable] Literal.

children.name: raw
children.comment: Creates a [UnaryOperation] from the given expression.

children.name: BinaryOperator
children.comment: A binary operator takes two expressions and performs an operation on them.

Creates a [BinaryOperation] from two given arguments.

If an argument is not an expression, it will be wrapped in an appropriate
literal.

 * A (positive) number will be encapsulated in a [Number] Literal,
 * A string will be encapsulated in a [Variable] Literal.

children.name: raw
children.comment: Creates a new [BinaryOperation] from two given expressions.

children.name: Expression
children.comment:
Any Expression supports basic mathematical operations like
addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, power and negate.

Furthermore, any expression can be differentiated with respect to
a given variable. Also expressions know how to simplify themselves.

There are different classes of expressions:

* Literals (see [Literal])

    * Number Literals (see [Number])
    * Variable Literals (see [Variable])
    * Vector Literals (see [Vector])
    * Interval Literals (see [IntervalLiteral])
* Operators (support auto-wrapping of parameters into Literals)

    * Unary Operators (see [UnaryOperator])
    * Binary Operators (see [BinaryOperator])
* Functions (see [MathFunction])

    * Pre-defined Functions (see [DefaultFunction])
    * Composite Functions (see [CompositeFunction])
    * Custom Functions (see [CustomFunction])

Pre-defined functions are [Exponential], [Log], [Ln], nth-[Root], [Sqrt],
[Sin], [Cos] and [Tan].
Add operator. Creates a [Plus] expression.
Subtract operator. Creates a [Minus] expression.
Multiply operator. Creates a [Times] expression.
Divide operator. Creates a [Divide] expression.
Power operator. Creates a [Power] expression.

children.name: unary-
children.comment: Unary minus operator. Creates a [UnaryMinus] expression.

children.name: derive
children.comment: Derives this expression with respect to the given variable.

children.name: simplify
children.comment:
Returns a simplified version of this expression.
Subclasses should overwrite this method, if applicable.

children.name: evaluate
children.comment: Evaluates this expression according to given type and context.

children.name: toString
children.comment: Sublcasses should override this method.

children.name: _toExpression
children.comment:
Converts the given argument to a valid expression.

Returns the argument, if it is already an expression.
Else wraps the argument in a [Number] or [Variable] Literal.

Throws ArgumentError, if given arg is not an Expression, num oder String.

__Note__: Does not handle negative numbers, will treat them as positives!

children.name: _isNumber
children.comment:
Returns true, if the given expression is a constant literal and its value
matches the given value.

children.name: Interval
children.comment:
An [Interval] is defined by its minimum and maximum values, where
_min <= max_.

This implementation offers basic interval arithmetic operations like
addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Operations always
return a new interval and will not modify the existing ones. Additionally
this class implementions comparison relations for intervals.

This implementation (partly) supports unbounded intervals with borders
at +/- infinity and empty sets.

Operator and comparison definitions are based on: 
_Bohlender, Gerd, and Ulrich Kulisch. 2010.
["Deï¬nition of the Arithmetic Operations and Comparison Relations for an Interval Arithmetic Standard"]
(http://interval.louisiana.edu/reliable-computing-journal/volume-15/no-1/reliable-computing-15-pp-36-42.pdf).
Reliable Computing 15 (1): 36â42._

__Note__: This implementation does not offer a complete set of operations yet:

* No handling of unbounded intervals in operators.
* No proper rounding.

Performs an interval addition.

    [a, b] + [c, d] = [a + c, b + d]

children.name: unary-
children.comment:
Unary minus on intervals.

    -[a, b] = [-b, -a]

Performs an interval subtraction.

    [a, b] + [c, d] = [a - d, b - c]

Performs an interval multiplication.

    [a, b] * [c, d] = [min(ac, ad, bc, bd), max(ac, ad, bc, bd)]

Performs an interval division.

    [a, b] * [c, d] = [a, b] * (1/[c, d]) = [a, b] * [1/d, 1/c]

__Note:__ Does not handle division by zero and throws an [ArgumentError] instead.

Equals operator on intervals.

    [a, b] == [c, d], if a == c && b == d

Less than operator on intervals.

    [a, b] < [c, d], if a < c && b < d

Less or equal than operator on intervals.

    [a, b] <= [c, d], if a <= c && b <= d

Greater than operator on intervals.

    [a, b] > [c, d], if a > c && b > d

Greater or equal than operator on intervals.

    [a, b] >= [c, d], if a >= c && b >= d

children.name: glb
children.comment: Returns the greatest lower bound.

children.name: lub
children.comment: Returns the least upper bound.

children.name: includes
children.comment:
Inclusion relation. Returns true, if the given interval is included
in this interval.

    [a, b] subset of [c, d] <=> c <= a && b >= d

children.name: contains
children.comment:
Element-of relation. Returns true, if given element is included
in this interval.
Defined on a real number i and an interval:

    i element of [a, b] <=> a <= i && i <= b

children.name: containsZero
children.comment: Returns true, if this interval contains zero (min <= 0 <= max).

children.name: isPositive
children.comment: Returns true, if this interval is positive (min >= 0)

children.name: isBound
children.comment: Returns true, if neither min or max values are infinite.

children.name: isEmpty
children.comment: Returns true, if this is the empty set.

children.name: _min
children.comment: Returns the minimal value of four given values.

children.name: _max
children.comment: Returns the maximum value of four given values.

children.name: length
children.comment: Returns the length of this interval.

children.name: min
children.comment: Interval borders.

children.name: max
children.comment: Interval borders.

children.name: _emptySet
children.comment: True, if this represents the empty set.

children.name: _emptyInterval
children.comment: Immutable singleton instance of empty set.

Creates a new interval with given borders.

The parameter min must be smaller or equal than max for the interval
to work properly.

children.name: empty
children.comment: Returns an immutable empty set.

children.name: _empty
children.comment: Internal constructor for an empty set.

children.name: Point3D
children.comment:
A point in 3-dimensional space.
This implementation supplies common mathematical operations on points.

Returns a new point which position is determined by moving the old point
along the given vector.
Returns the [Vector3] pointing from the given point to this point.

children.name: unary-
children.comment: Negates the point's components.

Checks for equality. Two points are considered equal, if their coordinates
match.

children.name: lerp
children.comment: Performs a linear interpolation between two points.

children.name: toVec3
children.comment: Transforms the point to its vector representation.

children.name: toVec4
children.comment:
Transforms the point to its homogeneous vector4 representation.
The w component is set to 1.
Creates a new Point3D with the given coordinates.

children.name: vec
children.comment: Creates a new Point3D from given vector3 / vector4.

children.name: splat
children.comment: Creates a new Point3D and "splats" the given value to each coordinate.

children.name: zero
children.comment: Creates a new Point3D at the coordinate origin.
